title: Norm Robinson
text:
Norman "Latchem" Robinson (17 October 1900 – 18 March 1980) was an Australian professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer, coach, selector and club administrator for the <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain Tigers</a> club in Sydney and a <a href="City%20vs%20Country%20Origin">City</a>, <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20state%20rugby%20league%20team">State</a> and <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">National</a> selector and manager. He also served as NSW and Australian coach in 1948 and 1958 respectively.
Playing career.
Robinson was graded at <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain</a> in 1922 as a halfback. He was a member of the <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain Tigers</a> team that won the Premiership in the <a href="1924%20NSWRFL%20season">1924 NSWRFL season</a>. Robinson was selected in the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20rugby%20league%20team">New South Wales rugby league team</a> between 1925 and 1926, playing a total of 5 games for the Blues. He played in the <a href="Maher%20Cup">Maher Cup</a> for Cootamundra in 1928, gaining representative selection for Southern Division in a match against Great Britain. Robinson then returned to Sydney and continued playing for Balmain. The final years of his career were spent playing for <a href="Yanco%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Yanco</a>'s club.
Coaching career.
Robinson had three separate coaching spells with the Balmain club. He coached the <a href="Balmain%20Tigers">Balmain Tigers</a> in 1930, 1944, 1945, 1946, 1947, 1954, 1955 and 1956 before retiring. He was coach of New South Wales in 1948. Also, in 1953, he coached the American "All Stars" during their tour of Australia. He was manager of the <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">Australian</a> team in the <a href="1957%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1957 Rugby League World Cup</a>. He was appointed coach of the <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">Australian</a> team for the 1958 <a href="The%20Ashes%20%28rugby%20league%29">Ashes</a> series against the touring <a href="Great%20Britain%20Lions">Great Britain Lions</a>. The British won the series 2–1 after winning Game 2 in <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a> and Game 3 in Sydney.
Administrative career.
Robinson was for many years after his playing retirement a Secretary-Manager of the Balmain Leagues Club. Together with the St George administrator <a href="Arthur%20Justice">Snowy Justice</a>, Robinson's former representative playing peer, he was one of the seminal forces behind the establishment of the <a href="Club%20Managers%27%20Association%20Australia">Club Managers' Association</a> of Australia at its foundation in 1964. Robinson was awarded a Life Membership of that organisation for outstanding service to the club industry.
Accolades.
The Wests Tigers Team of the Century was announced in 2004, encompassing the best players from both Balmain and Western Suburbs. Norm Robinson was voted the "Coach of the Century".
The "Latchem" Robinson stand at <a href="Leichhardt%20Oval">Leichhardt Oval</a>, Balmain's home ground, is named in his honour. Norm Robinson died 12 days before the opening of the stand by <a href="Neville%20Wran">Neville Wran</a>, premier of New South Wales and Tiger supporter, in 1980.
His largely attended funeral was held at St. Thomas's Church, <a href="Rozelle%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Rozelle, New South Wales</a> on 21 March 1980 and he was cremated at Northern Suburbs Crematorium.
